    <descript>
      <abstract>The dataset contains locations and attributes of Engine Local Alarm Districts in Washington, DC 2006</abstract>
      <purpose>This data is used for the planning and management of Washington, D.C. by local government agencies.</purpose>
    </descript>

  <dataqual>
    <attracc>
      <attraccr>Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. 

Engine Local Alarm Districts were checked for proper connectivity between bordering districts.  Engine Local Alarm Districts were also checked to ensure snapping to Street Center Lines.  In cases of "imaginary lines," alarm districts could not always be snapped to Street Center Lines.   

Not validated by source and/or responsible agency.</attraccr>
    </attracc>
    <logic>Validated by source and/or responsible agency.</logic>
    <complete>Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. 

Dataset is complete to the provided written documentation.  Any service area(s) not represented or area(s) of the city not covered by service areas, are a result of possilbe missing information not provided by originator.

Not validated by source and/or responsible agency.</complete>
    <posacc>
      <horizpa>
        <horizpar>A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.</horizpar>
      </horizpa>
      <vertacc>
        <vertaccr>A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable </vertaccr>
      </vertacc>
    </posacc>

      </srcinfo>
      <procstep>
        <procdesc>Dataset copied from the CD obtained from Washington, DC 2005

Engine Local Alarm Districts were digitized manually snapping to the DC Street Center Line Dataset.  

Documentation was provided by FEMS describing the boundaries for each Engine Company.  The process involved reading written boundaries and tracing the street center line from start to finish, thus creating a new polygon record for each Engine Company.  

Some descriptions are clear, while others are open to differing interpretation.  For this reason, FEMS officials were consulted with to ensure proper coverage in areas where the descriptions are obscure.  Maps showing first round digitization were delivered to each Engine Captain for an opportunity to dispute or confirm interpreted boundaries.  Some areas of the city were not covered by any Engine Company according to written descriptions.  These areas were brought to the attention of FEMS officials.

Once all Maps were returned, hand written comments and boundaries from the Captains and the Deputy fire Chief, were compared to one another.  Adjustments were made to the second round of digitization resulting in a more accurate account of Local Alarm Districts.</procdesc>
        <procdate>2005</procdate>
